ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Skills in stop motion animation in a multitude of different mediums. Worked with humor and storytelling

Developed an understanding of principles such as persistence of vision, the frame, shadows and light, and other aspects of animation. Worked with editing and animation software to produce animated projects

You learn about the history of animation and moving images and see how moving images are used across cultures through viewing assignments and guest lectures. You learn how to use the stop motion and film softwares like Dragonframe and Premier Pro as well as various other techniques to create handmade animations.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
The breadth of material used was definitely a strength of this course. Being able to animate with references to history was a really interesting opportunity. The guest artists had really insightful commentary on how to create art.

The only weakness is that many of the things introduced in class would be much better in person, as the Edison museum. I think working with digital animation at some point would remedy this

The course was very broad and approached animation in a number of different ways. The projects were all varied and challenging. However, this course suffered a little from being virtual since it's a studio art course

The strengths were that we were pushed to learn a lot of different ways to create moving images by hand. We were given constraints on assignments that pushed me creatively and led me to make art that I would not have made on my own. The weaknesses were that class time could've been used more for making the art and less for guest lectures and discussions.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
I feel that many of the guest artists and museum visits was severely hindered by virtual learning. Many historical objects are just not the same when viewing from the screen, or through a PowerPoint.

The actual classes, discussions, and screening were engaging, and I felt geared well towards the virtual space.

Everything about the course was set as up as well as it could be for the pandemic and materials that students needed were even shipped to their locations. All of the shortcomings were due to zoom itself (poor audio, inefficient screen sharing, etc.)
I think we could've had shorter lectures over zoom and more time built in to make the animations.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you are interested in hand animation, I would definitely take this class. For someone who is only tangentially related, I think the workload would be very daunting, as each project could take upwards of 25 hours to complete.
If you are interested in animation and are willing to do a lot of work I would recommend this class.
